body.p: TROUT RUN Rev. Allison came down to help at the church, Thursday. Mr. and Mrs. Myhres spent Wed- nesday evening at Zimmerman’s. Lloyd McNulty came up from Sparta Sunday with his parents. Mr. and Mrs. Earl Horswill and children spent Sunday at Tomah. Mr. and Mrs. R. Zimmerman were recent visitors at Peter Hoagenson’s. Mr. and Mrs. Axel Odeen and chil- dren spent Sunday at the George Det- tinger home in your city. Mrs. Alex McNab returned to Rice Lake Wednesday. The ladies met at the church to rip off paper Monday, and had the pleasure of her company and help. Ralph Hostrawser, Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Avery, Mr. and Mrs. Jule Nort- man and Donovan, Mr. and Mrs. Jer- ome Annett and daughter spent Sun- day at Colby’s. The many friends of Miss Elnora Burge who has been so very sick, are glad she is a trifle better. She entered the Krohn hospital this morn- ing for treatment. Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Avery will go to the Harvey Gilbertson home Wed- nesday, where he has employment. Fremont Avery is still sick in the U. S. hospital at Hot Springs, Ark. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Enger and son of Madison came Friday and vis- ited over Sunday with their daughter, Mrs. Stanley Stratton. Mrs. Enger remained for a longer visit. Other guests Sunday were Mr. and Mrs. H. E. Berg and Dean, and Mr. and Mrs. Carl Straton. Mrs. Will Colby received a message from John Brinkman of Waycross, Georgia, that his wife died Feb. 24. She was formerly Miss Florence Head, one of the fine teachers of Jackson county years ago. A num- ber of years ago the Brinkmans went south to live. For the past three years she suffered of dropsy and the past year was confined to her bed most of the time. The funeral was held Tuesday, and she was laid to rest in the nearby cemetery. Her sister, Mrs. Ed Hostrawser (Mary- Head) is also resting there. Mrs. Brinkman visited here several years ago and always kept in touch with former friends by reading the B-J. She leaves an adopted son and her husband, who have the deepest sym- pathy of old friends in Jackson coun- ty.
